name: ITALIAN GAME
idea: The Bc4 directly targets f7, the weakest point on the board at the start of the game (defended only by the King). White can choose between a rapid attack (Ng5, sacrifices on f7) or slow positional play with d3, 0-0, c3 then d4. This is the classic opening of the Italian Renaissance, ideal for learning the fundamental principles of open games.
errors_white: Premature d4 without c3: after ...exd4, White loses the center and time
Neglecting castling: the King in the center is vulnerable to tactics on the e-file
Qh5 too early (Scholar's Mate): easily parried by ...Qe7 or ...g6, and the Queen is exposed
errors_black: Premature ...Nxe4?: allows the Legal Trap with Bxf7+! or Nxf7 winning
...f6?: horribly weakens the a2-g8 diagonal and allows devastating sacrifices
Ignoring the threat on f7: always watch for Ng5 or Qb3 attacking f7 and b7
development: Develop to e3 (solid, defends d4) or g5 (aggressive, pins Nf6)
Develop to c3 to control d5 and support d4
After 0-0, place Re1 on the semi-open e-file
Kingside castling is priority - the King is safe and the Rook is active
Avoid premature sorties (Qh5, Qf3) - keep flexible
Plan c3-d4 to build an ideal pawn center

traps.name: Legal Trap
traps.desc: After 4.Nc3 Nxe4?? 5.Bxf7+! Kxf7 6.Nxe4 wins. AVOID: Never take e4 with the Knight! Play ...Bc5 or ...Be7 instead to develop normally.

traps.name: Fried Liver Attack
traps.desc: 4.Ng5 threatens Nxf7. If ...d5 5.exd5 Nxd5?? 6.Nxf7! wins. AVOID: After ...d5 exd5, play ...Na5! (not Nxd5) to chase the Bishop and recapture d5 later.

traps.name: Scholar's Mate
traps.desc: Qh5 + Bc4 threatens Qxf7#. Beginner's trap! AVOID: Play ...Qe7! (defends f7 and threatens Qxe4+), or ...g6 then ...Nf6. The White Queen will be misplaced.

variants.name: Giuoco Piano
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 g1f3 b8c6 f1c4 f8c5 c2c3 g8f6 d2d4 e5d4 c3d4 c5b4
variants.white_plan: Accept the isolated pawns after Nc3 or Bd2. The d4-e4 pawn center gives space and open lines for attacking.
variants.black_plan: Put pressure on e4 with ...d5 at the right moment. The Bb4 hinders White's development. Look to exchange pieces.

variants.name: Evans Gambit
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 g1f3 b8c6 f1c4 f8c5 b2b4 c5b4 c2c3 b4a5
variants.white_plan: Sacrifice the b4 pawn for ultra-rapid development. After d4, White has a powerful center and all pieces active.
variants.black_plan: Accept the gambit and consolidate. Play ...d6, ...Bb6 and return the pawn if necessary to complete development safely.

variants.name: Two Knights Defense
variants.uci: e2e4 e7e5 g1f3 b8c6 f1c4 g8f6 f3g5 d7d5 e4d5 c6a5
variants.white_plan: After Bb5+ c6 dxc6 bxc6, White has an extra pawn but Black has strong initiative. Very tactical play!
variants.black_plan: Immediate counter-attack! ...Na5 chases the Bc4 and prepares ...c6 to recover the d5 pawn with good play.
